subtasks.title: Design Store Structure
subtasks.description: Define the structure and modules of the Zustand store based on current and anticipated state needs.
subtasks.details: Create a new directory (e.g., src/stores) and design the main store file(s), outlining state slices and actions for features like history, chart data, and user input. Consider modularization and middleware for debugging or persistence if needed.

subtasks.title: Identify Shared State for Migration
subtasks.description: Map out all state variables and logic currently managed by useState and passed via props-drilling.
subtasks.details: Review App.jsx and all relevant child components to list every piece of state and updater function that is shared across multiple component levels.

subtasks.title: Migrate State and Logic to Zustand Store
subtasks.description: Move identified state variables and their update logic from useState into the new Zustand store.
subtasks.details: Implement the state and actions in the Zustand store, ensuring all business logic and side effects are preserved. Use best practices such as selective subscriptions and middleware where appropriate.

subtasks.title: Refactor Components to Use Zustand
subtasks.description: Update components to consume state and actions directly from the Zustand store instead of via props.
subtasks.details: Replace useState and props usage with the appropriate useStore hook calls in each component. Ensure components subscribe only to the state slices they need.

subtasks.title: Remove Props-Drilling Chains
subtasks.description: Eliminate all unnecessary props passing related to shared state throughout the component tree.
subtasks.details: Clean up component interfaces and remove any props that are no longer needed due to direct Zustand access. Refactor or simplify component hierarchies as appropriate.

subtasks.title: Perform Regression Testing
subtasks.description: Verify that all features and state-dependent behaviors work as expected after the migration.
subtasks.details:
Run existing tests and perform manual testing to ensure the application behaves identically to the pre-migration version. Pay special attention to edge cases and shared state updates.

subtasks.title: Install TanStack Query Dependencies
subtasks.description: Add TanStack Query (react-query) and related packages to the project to enable standardized data fetching and caching.
subtasks.details: Run the appropriate package manager command (e.g., npm install @tanstack/react-query) to install the required dependencies.

subtasks.title: Set Up QueryClientProvider in App Entry
subtasks.description: Initialize QueryClient and wrap the application with QueryClientProvider to provide query context throughout the component tree.
subtasks.details: Create a QueryClient instance and wrap the root component (e.g., App.jsx) with <QueryClientProvider client={queryClient}> to enable TanStack Query features across the app.[2][3]

subtasks.title: Design Custom Data Fetching Hook (useDistanceMatrix)
subtasks.description: Implement a reusable custom hook for fetching distance matrix data, encapsulating query logic and queryKey management.
subtasks.details: Create a useDistanceMatrix hook using useQuery, define a suitable queryKey, and structure the hook to accept parameters for origin/destination addresses.[2][3]

subtasks.title: Mock API Responses for Development
subtasks.description: Set up mock data and API response logic within the custom hook to simulate real API behavior and validate integration structure.
subtasks.details: Within useDistanceMatrix, temporarily return hardcoded or mock data instead of making real API calls, ensuring the hook and provider integration work as expected.

subtasks.title: Integrate Custom Hook into UI Components
subtasks.description: Connect the useDistanceMatrix hook to relevant UI components (e.g., AddressInput) to trigger data fetching based on user input.
subtasks.details: Invoke the custom hook in the AddressInput component, passing user-provided addresses as parameters, and use the returned data, loading, and error states for rendering.[2]

subtasks.title: Handle Loading and Error States in UI
subtasks.description: Implement UI logic to display loading indicators and error messages based on the hook's state, ensuring a robust user experience.
subtasks.details: Use the isPending (or isLoading) and error properties from the hook to conditionally render loading spinners or error messages in the AddressInput component.[2]

subtasks.description: Add comprehensive error handling to the API integration, covering network issues, invalid responses, and quota errors.
subtasks.details: Detect and handle errors from the API, such as invalid API keys, exceeded quotas, or malformed requests. Provide fallback logic and ensure errors are logged for debugging.[1][3]

subtasks.title: Integrate User Feedback Mechanisms

subtasks.details: Display loading spinners during API requests and show user-friendly error messages when issues occur. Ensure the UI updates appropriately based on the hook's state.

subtasks.details: Use client-side caching (e.g., via TanStack Query) to store recent API responses and avoid unnecessary requests. Track API usage and implement rate limiting or warnings to prevent excessive costs.[2][3]

subtasks.title: Dependency Installation

subtasks.title: CSS Adjustments

subtasks.details: Update styles to use transforms and absolute positioning as required by the virtualizer, ensuring the table layout remains consistent and scrolls smoothly.

subtasks.title: Performance Testing with Large Datasets

subtasks.details:

subtasks.title: Create ErrorBoundary Component
subtasks.description: Develop a reusable ErrorBoundary React component that catches JavaScript errors in its child component tree, logs the errors, and displays a user-friendly fallback UI.
subtasks.details: Implement ErrorBoundary using React lifecycle methods such as getDerivedStateFromError and componentDidCatch. Ensure the fallback UI is informative and actionable. Allow for customization of fallback messages based on context.

subtasks.title: Implement Global Error Logging
subtasks.description: Integrate a global error logging mechanism within the ErrorBoundary component to capture and report errors to a centralized logging service or console.
subtasks.details: In componentDidCatch, send error details and component stack information to an external monitoring service (e.g., Sentry) or log them for debugging. Ensure sensitive data is not exposed in logs.

subtasks.title: Update Zustand Store for Loading State
subtasks.description: Extend the Zustand store to include global loading state management, enabling consistent tracking of loading status across all async operations.
subtasks.details: Add loading state variables and actions to the Zustand store. Provide hooks for components and async flows to set and clear loading states. Ensure the store supports multiple concurrent loading operations if needed.

subtasks.title: Develop Unified Loading Spinner Component
subtasks.description: Create a centralized LoadingSpinner component that visually represents the global loading state and can be reused throughout the application.
subtasks.details: Design the spinner to be visually consistent and accessible. Connect it to the Zustand store so it automatically displays or hides based on the global loading state.

subtasks.title: Integrate ErrorBoundary and Loading Spinner into Async Flows
subtasks.description: Wrap async operations and key UI sections with the ErrorBoundary component and ensure all async flows update the global loading state, triggering the unified spinner.
subtasks.details: Refactor async logic to set loading state before and after operations. Place ErrorBoundary components at appropriate locations (feature, layout, or route level) to maximize resilience and user experience.

subtasks.title: Comprehensive Error and Recovery Testing
subtasks.description: Test the application for various error scenarios and loading states to ensure graceful degradation, correct error logging, and proper loading feedback.
subtasks.details:
Simulate component errors, network failures, and edge cases. Verify that errors are caught, logged, and displayed with the correct fallback UI. Ensure loading spinner appears and disappears as expected. Test recovery flows such as retry and reload.
